text: parents in britain now pay the highest childcare bills in europe according to a national survey published today which shows that costs have soared to record levels the national childcare charity daycare trust which compiled the survey of the costs of nurseries childminders and afterschool clubs said the rising bills threatened the success of the governments childcare strategy the typical cost of a nursery place for a child under two is now a week or more than a year up from last year the survey shows this compares with the average weekly household income of in parts of the country particularly london and the southeast the cost of a nursery place is much higher typically a week in inner london or more than a year with some parents paying much more parents in the uk pay threequarters of the cost of child care with the government paying most of the rest plus a small contribution by employers in most other european countries parents foot just of the bill the daycare trust says the high cost of childcare in britain is a key reason why only of parents with dependent children use formal childcare services all the time the director of the daycare trust stephen burke said parents need more financial help towards childcare costs to enable them to work and to give their children a good start in life the government should improve the childcare tax credit and do more to encourage employers to help their staff with childcare costs affordable childcare for all is crucial to achieving many of the governments policies from ending child poverty to raising educational attainment rosemary murphy who is chief executive of the national day nurseries association added we are urging the government to give more careful thought to how it can support parents with the cost of childcare and give employers greater incentives to support the childcare costs of their staff the education minister cathy ashton said the government wanted to improve access to affordable high quality childcare we are giving financial help to low and middle income families to pay for childcare and are funding free early education for all fouryearolds and soon all threeyearolds she added this government has spent an unprecedented amount on supporting working parents with m a day now spent on supporting parents with childcare costs she said that since the government had created new childcare places for almost million children by this would grow to places for more than million children she claimed

text: husbands who claim their partners nagging or infidelity drove them to kill will face much tougher sentences under a government shakeup of socalled crimes of passion ministers are secretly reviewing the defence of provocation which has its origins in the bygone tradition of men fighting duels under which a defendant can evade a murder charge by arguing that their victim did or said something that made them lose control ministers argue that it reflects a medieval view of marriage in which a man whose honour is insulted by a domineering or unfaithful wife is entitled to fatal revenge rather than a divorce it also encourages defendants to blacken the victims name in court painting her as a bad wife the review will prompt impassioned debate over modern relationships with critics likely to argue that men instinctively respond differently than women to infidelity and that feminising the law is unfair this defence institutionalises the blaming of the victim i killed her but it was all her fault and we say we are going to put the victim at the heart of the crim inal justice system said a whitehall source we put a high value on human life and have high standards of responsibility times have changed we dont have duels and we dont see mens ownership of their wives in the same way the provocation defence cannot secure a killers acquittal but reduces the charge from murder carrying a life sentence to manslaughter with a much shorter or even suspended sentence solicitorgeneral harriet harman home secretary david blunkett and the lord chancellors department are still discussing the reforms leading options include scrapping the provocation defence altogether understood to be harmans preference or strictly limiting the circumstances in which provocation could be claimed making clear that sexual jealousy is not enough ministers are also studying the us system of homicide counts under which different grades of murder carry different tariffs the review follows the case of madeleine humeswho was killed by her husband les a solicitor after she confessed to an affair with her karate instructor the court heard last year how their teenage daughter tried to seize the knife from humes as he repeatedly stabbed her mother humes who said in court he just saw this red mist got seven years for manslaughter leaving his wifes family furious if madeleine had survived and he had been charged only with attempted murder or gbh he would have got more of a sentence than that says paula watt madeleines sister but he killed her so he gets less what kind of signal is that sending to people all the way through les was seen as a victim maddie wasnt heard at all home office research on homicides found that women were much more likely to be killed by a husband or lover than a stranger one of the most dangerous flashpoints is a woman leaving the relationship even if as in the humeses case the marriage was not previously known to be violent using the defence requires defendants to show it was reasonable given their character for them to have responded by killing but there is little definition of what counts as provocation we call it the nagging and shagging defence classically it will be either she was sleeping with someone else or that she nagged him said solicitor harriet wistrich of campaign group justice for women but if it is simply that she is leaving you is that enough of an excuse for murder several women who have killed abusive partners famously sara thornton have claimed provocation arguing that they snapped after years of putting up with domestic violence but ministers believe these cases could be covered by extending the law on self defence to cover cases where the woman was not responding to an immediate attack but was still effectively killing to save herself highprofile cases involving provocation include joseph mcgrail who walked free in with a suspended sentence for kicking his wife to death after pleading provocation on the grounds that she was an alcoholic and swore at him the judge said the dead woman would have tried the patience of a saint

text: britains fathers are to blame for failing to ask for more flexible working practices and adhering to a longhours culture the confederation of british industry said yesterday as a report claimed the countrys work culture stops men spending more time caring for their children susan anderson director of human resource policy at the cbi said employers recognised they needed to offer flexible hours but that it was up to fathers to call for this men still see themselves as the main breadwinners she said and while employers are equally open to requests for more flexibility from men as women the truth of the matter is they originate more from women but the charity fathers direct insisted fathers were too scared to ask for increased flexibility in a culture in which fathers work the longest hours in europe with one in eight spending hours a week in the office young fathers need to feel very secure in their careers and they believe that asking for flexibility is seen as a lack of commitment which makes them more vulnerable said a spokesman jack osullivan theres a different culture around worklife benefits for women its more legitimised for female workers to work parttime for instance but men are scared to ask for this the debate arose as the equal opportunities commission published its report working fathers earning and caring which found fathers of children under five spend more than two hours a day looking after their youngsters compared with just minutes a generation ago but that they would do more if they were offered increased flexibility the research which incorporates an analysis of a government survey of employees and a second of employers confirms that traditional gender roles still exist with of fathers working fulltime compared with of mothers and twofifths of fathers still working more than hours a week the maximum specified under the eu working time directive with the increase in mothers returning to work fathers are increasingly handson in the provision of childcare but such daily provision decreases for fathers who work plus hours a week a quota worked by fewer than of mothers such fathers then make up for the time away from their families at the weekend but while fathers are displaying revolutionary behaviour in combining the roles of both breadwinner and caregiver just opt to work parttime compared with of mothers while only make use of flexitime and jobshare crucially twothirds of fathers believe working parttime would affect their career progression compared with of mothers fathers expectations of whether their employers will offer worklife balance practices are low an expectation often matched by the reality with promotion of familysensitive policies variable and only threefifths of employers compared with fourfifths of workers supporting the idea of worklife balance the research comes just before the introduction in april of statutory paternity leave and a workplace standard which will enable parents of children under six to ask for flexible working practices though there will be no compulsion for the employer to grant them last night the reports coauthor margaret obrien of the university of east anglia described the introduction of paid paternity leave as a catalyst for a national debate about how fathers balance their economic and emotional commitments to children and partners julie mellor the chairwoman of the eoc added the vast majority of all parents believe everyone should be able to balance their work and home lives in the way they want

text: new parents could get more time off work and further financial assistance under proposals presented today by senior cabinet ministers the plans were unveiled by the chancellor gordon brown and the trade and industry secretary patricia hewitt as they highlighted familyfriendly measures already due for introduction in april mr brown and ms hewitt launched a document balancing work and family life enhancing choice and support for parents which said the government will examine the case for extending the period of paid paternity leave andor introduce unpaid paternity leave under plans announced previously by mr brown as of april this year fathers will be entitled to two weeks statutory paternity pay in addition ministers will consider whether to extend paid paternity leave in cases of multiple births and disabled children since december parents have been entitled to weeks unpaid parental leave to be taken in a childs first five years which can be taken in blocks of up to four weeks a year ministers will now consider the case for allowing parents to use all that leave in one block at the end of maternity paternity or adoption leave the government will also consider whether to allow fathers time off to attend antenatal classes in other moves ministers will also consider allowing a mother on paid maternity leave to claim help with childcare costs for a new child in order to settle that child into childcare before the mother returns to work the proposals were outlined as mr brown and ms hewitt sought to highlight the financial assistance which will be available to a large number of families with the introduction in april of the child tax credit and working tax credit mr brown said for most people the combination of tax credits and child benefit would provide assistance of a week for a first child he emphasised that the tax credits would be paid direct to mothers aprils new tax credits are the biggest financial boost for mothers since the introduction of child benefit and evidence shows that money paid direct to mothers is more likely to be spent on the child than if it goes to fathers up to bn will be transferred from dads to mums for their children we want to put families first by helping parents as they do the most important and difficult job of all getting their children off to a good start in life mr brown cited an icm poll which found that twothirds of people believe that all support for children should be paid to the mother and only believe it should be paid to the father asked whether the increase in national insurance contributions due in april would effectively wipe out the benefit to flow from tax credits mr brown said many families even after the national insurance rise as the result of the improvements in child support will be better off and of course people will be paying towards a better health service and i believe when people see the new investment that is taking place in the nhs then they will see the benefit of these changes

text: john baker who is helping to bring up a second brood of children believes attitudes to fathers have changed significantly over the past two decades but says they still face discrimination in the workplace there is a tendency for employers to expect men to put work first and families second he said employers seem to be more tolerant of women who put their families first and work second mr baker a university lecturer has two children a girl and a boy by an earlier relationship and two boys seven and five from his current marriage he says he has always tried to do as much as possible to help raise his children but finds that society now accepts such an attitude more readily mr baker said fifteen years ago it really wasnt the thing at least in the north of england where i lived then for men to be closely involved in child care men drew the curtains when they needed to change a childs nappy now it is an acceptable thing for men to do its acceptable to be seen pushing a pram or spending time with your children in the playground he was pleased more facilities were provided for men and babies for example i found i didnt have to gatecrash womens toilets in search of changing facilities but he still encounters some prejudice when i went to antenatal classes before the birth of my third and fourth children i found that i was treated as if i was an incompetent male when in fact i probably knew more than most because i had been there before but it is in the workplace where mr baker a senior lecturer in social policy at the university of brighton says men face most difficulties many employers do not give fathers enough time off i think it is particularly true of senior positions executives are expected to be prepared to work all hours and fly abroad at a moments notice fathers need to be encouraged to spend more time with children contact with children enhances life for both parents and children those who miss out miss out on the richest part of human life social policies should be encouraging a balance between work and home life if children miss out on contact with parents then there will be serious social consequences

text: fathers carry out a third of all childcare in the uk according to a report to be published today from the equal opportunities commission the surprise findings have prompted julie mellor chair of the eoc to call for a new debate on the role of fatherhood the role of british fathers is changing fast and we need to negotiate that new role at home at work and in terms of government policy ms mellor says in an interview with the guardian the eocs report working fathers earning and caring found that the time men spend with their children has increased from less than minutes a day in the mids to two hours on the average weekday by the late s at weekends it is significantly more averaging around six and a half hours each day according to ms mellor the findings mean that the uk needs a shift in the culture which actually legitimises mens roles so that they feel more confident to ask for flexibility at work at present men have low expectations of securing worklife balance practices and still see themselves as the main breadwinner with of them saying that work makes it difficult to fulfil their family duties men feel they are forced to work longer hours to provide for their children but its not what they want to do they want flexibility says ms mellor from april the government is introducing a workplace standard which will enable parents of children under six to ask their employers for flexible working practices though there will be no compulsion on the employer to grant them ms mellor wants the standard extended to parents of older children and will be watching the uptake among men preempting objections from employers that such measures would increase costs for businesses the eoc has surveyed employers who have introduced flexible working practices research showed that eight out of employers felt they fostered good employment relations and twothirds agreed they improved staff motivation although believed they increased overall costs nine out of who had implemented such measures found them cost effective interview page letters page

text: q i am a yearold teacher with over years experience in all types of special needs and mainstream teaching working with children from nursery to secondary age i have had a successful career and am a good teacher i love working with children particularly those whose lives do not run smoothly for one or more reasons however i would love to put my energies into something which does not involve teaching i dont know which area of work to focus on and it may be that my present level of experience and expertise can be utilised elsewhere still involving work with children maybe i could find a different type of job altogether i have tons of energy patience initiative common sense and compassion i am good at working as part of a team and have found that a sense of humour and optimism are essential in all types of work cok a i think you should play to your strengths and as you say that you love working with children you may have found a champion in the chancellor gordon brown in his last budget he promised a powerful boost to workplace nurseries and crches by using tax and national insurance incentives to encourage employers to expand the number of schemes there are only workplace nurseries across britain but as part of its national childcare strategy and focus on balancing work and family life the government hopes to encourage more employers to sponsor workplace nurseries this may be one area of work worth exploring you could approach large employers in your area who may be thinking of setting up workplace nurseries it is estimated that over the next three years around new workers are needed to meet the growing demand for childcare professionals people with your level of experience are also in demand to run outofschool clubs sometimes called kids clubs open before and after school and all day long during school holidays giving to yearolds a safe and enjoyable place to play meet or sometimes catch up on homework they are not only a great place for youngsters to meet their friends they also offer a wide range of activities to keep them busy such as sports or drama arts and crafts or music depending on your own interests you would be responsible for organising and running or helping with anything from a breakfast club before school to a football team or holiday play scheme playworkers may also be employed by local government departments nhs hospital trusts voluntary organisations or private companies such as holiday operators and the leisure industry some playworkers are selfemployed and others work as consultants pay levels are set text: placing leaflets in gp surgeries spelling out the horrors of domestic violence is not the best way to help women leave abusive partners according to janet jackson many children think its the norm for their dad to hit their mum or sister says the year old mother of two what we need are workshops in schools telling girls and boys that its wrong only then can we break that cycle of violence this was her first piece of advice to the east birmingham forum on domestic violence whose management committee she joined a few months ago as the only board member who is a survivor of domestic violence she knows firsthand how difficult it is to leave an abusive relationship its not that easy to get out she says you feeled trapped in a spiders web your selfesteem and confidence are broken like a shattered vase you feel hopeless what finally gave jackson the strength to leave was the support she received from waits women acting in todays society a birminghambased community organisation she was put in touch with by the police after she tried to commit suicide she developed a close friendship with her waits domestic violence development worker who provided practical advice as well as emotional support i didnt want to move in to a hostel but joanna went with me to see it first which really helped says jackson shes always there for me day and night waits combination of onetoone training counselling and advocacy has gradually helped jackson to rebuild her confidence over the last year to the point where she is now setting up a survivors group for other black and minority ethnic women in her community actively contributes to the domestic violence forum and is a vocal member of waits planning committee i always wanted to have a voice but waits gave me the courage and faith in myself to believe that i have got something important to say she says it is this type of community leadership and participation that the government is anxious to foster rhetorically encouraging local people to take a lead in transforming their neighbourhoods is at the heart of its strategy to tackle social exclusion but while ministers recognise that grassroots organisations such as waits are often best placed to nurture local peoples skills and talents a report published today by thinktank demos argues that its policies are actually underming community groups ability to deliver the demands and expectations of central and local government with their strict performance criteria emphasis on quantitative outputs and formal participatory structures such as local strategic partnerships all act against community projects achieving their aims according to demos these groups are often motivated by political or moral values and see empowering people as their main priority not delivering government polices says helen mccarthy author of the report inside out rethinking inclusive communities if the government really trusts communitybased organisations then it has to recognise that they are not conventional service providers the report assesses the role played by independent grassroots organisations in building capacity building and leadership in local communities researchers surveyed more than community projects funded by the barrow cadbury trust an independent trust that commissioned the study to help it use its m annual grants provision more effectively respondents raised concerns that government was more interested in coopting them than allowing them to do what they are good at as a result many refused to accept financial support from statutory bodies for fear it would compromise their independence the local authority does not help community partnership it tries to determine and direct them said one community leader surveyed this is a view borne out by the community and council infighting that has dogged the governments new deal for communities ndc programme since its launch in a significant number of the projects across the country aimed at reviving britains poorest areas by giving local people the chance to devise their own solutions to the problems of their neighbourhood have run into trouble over allegations of government and council interference only last month britains leading tenant body was sacked from advising residents about a ndc scheme in kilburn north london tenant participation advisory service chief executive phil morgan comments the new deal was meant to be about working with communities not about imposing topdown solutions anita guy a waits trustee says government is purporting to be doing something about social exclusion but it has got to be people and organisations doing it independently for themselves she acknowledges the difficulties organisations like hers pose for funders we facilitiate people to do the things they want to do she explains if a funder asks us what we will do with their money all we can guarantee is that well involve a number of women who are not currently involved in their community we cant say how many meetings were going to have or what exact issues well be tackling because it depends what the women want to do but we do know that we will benefit them and the community suhvinder stubbs director of the barrow cadbury trust believes there is a need for fewer initiatives a simplified funding regime and more flexible local structures government is not playing to the strengths of communitybased organisations she says inside out calls on the government to recognise that peoplebased rather than paperbased solutions are the way to tackle social exclusion to trust communitybased organisations more and to create what it calls a new middle ground that reconciles the professional culture of formal partnership structures with the culture of grassroots organisations stubbs sees a role here for independent trusts in bridging this gap but not until councils learn how to work with them they feel threatened and fearful of us she says they cant control us so they ignore us barbara roche minister for social exclusion who will speak about simplified funding streams at todays launch of the report accepts there are difficulties but insists that positive changes are taking place for community groups at local level there is a real readjustment of power for all of us and that takes time she says but community organisers argue that they have yet to see local and national goverment relinquish control and a more handsoff approach is still needed to put local people in the driving seat the report makes clear that local people supported by community text: since on average women are paid less than men it seems natural to assume that any legislation for fairer pay would benefit women rather than men natural assumptions have their limits however and a report from the institute for social and economic research at the university of essex comes to the surprising conclusion that men are more likely to benefit from new laws governing fixedterm contracts and temporary employment since last year employers have been obliged to treat shorttermcontract workers and permanent staff equally the same wages and benefits must be available to both similar legislation is in the pipeline for temporary workers in both cases it is men who have the biggest gap to close to catch up with their permanent colleagues there is no noticeable division of gender between fixedterm and permanent workers the same proportion of men as women work on fixedterm contracts but up to now men have had more to lose from shortterm employment women on shortterm contracts earn an average less than women on permanent contracts men on shortterm contracts earn less than if they were permanent men who temp fall even further behind earning less women who temp do less well than women in permanent employment by about the same margin the biggest difference between how men and women work is that far more women work parttime than men almost always because of family commitments over the past decade the proportion of men in parttime employment has edged up slightly but it is still only by contrast of women in the workforce are parttimers as it happens parttimers do not do badly when their wages are compared pro rata to fulltimers earning between and less this disparity alone is not enough to explain the massive gap between mens and womens average earnings at best estimate but parttimers by nature are not always available to do overtime and overtime is one definite factor in the disparity the other is gender division of jobs the male it contractor may do less well than his permanent colleagues but he still does better than a teacher

text: the bizarre onoff tussle within the family behind the berkeley group building business seemed to have the makings of a reallife dynastystyle drama when it broke out last week tony k pidgley publicschool educated son of former barnardos boy tony senior founder of the empire announced he was planning a billion bid for his fathers business the initial publicity generated speculation about family disharmony and anger on the part of pidgley jnr over his fathers remarriage to a much younger woman but within hours pidgley jnr withdrew his tentative takeover offer and quashed suggestions of a family feud such public dramas are rare but whether they involve a powerful dynasty or a smallscale enterprise like a village shop or pub family firms can face conflicts and management dilemmas that need special handling a staggering per cent of all the businesses in the uk are family firms according to figures from the department of trade and industry theses businesses are such a large and vibrant part of the economy that the university of gloucester is now offering a parttime mba for family managers the first batch of students started the course last month and will learn how to manage conflict succession employment issues and growth the course is run in connection with kairos consulting a bristol company founded by john tucker who ran his own family business for seven years he says business relationships between relatives can often be fraught with difficulties succession planning is the major issue we deal with on a regular basis he says there can also be difficulties for nonfamily managers who are brought in to run the business but who still have to contend with family members who own it the attrition rate is extraordinarily high only about per cent of businesses stay in the family to the second generation and that drops to per cent by the time you reach the third generation the mba is a twoandahalfyear parttime course aimed to help second and thirdgeneration family business managers aside from business considerations most family firms tend to run relatively smoothly in the first generation an entrepreneur sets up the company and his or her spouse helps with the paper work the problems start when the son or daughter is expected to take up the reins sometimes the son lets call him jimmy does well when his father is running the business but there comes a time when he will have to go it alone says harry katz principal at financial adviser norwest consultants in middlesex the question is has jimmy got the skills and personality needed or is he just taking over because he is the son another problem is how the father reconciles his need for a retirement income with jimmys need to run a proper business there are occasions when the father takes a salary but doesnt work any more and jimmy is left with a millstone round his neck he may be working for a low salary on the promise of the business passing to him when the father dies he feels like it is slave labour and thats when resentment sets in says katz one of the options would be to buy out the fathers share of the business or to pay him dividends often however the fathers income in retirement depends heavily on how well his offspring run the business which means it is hard for him to stop meddling it is these issues that tucker tries to resolve for his clients the earlier you sort it out the better he says it can be very difficult for a son to accept that his father wants him to continue working at the firm under the direction of a new nonfamily managing director one issue often forgotten when entrepreneurs are building a business is the effect that their dedication can have on their young family tucker ran a training company from until but when he asked his children what life was like for them he got some surprising answers they told me about how the business was the only thing we talked about around the dinner table and why they would never go into a family business after this experience for this reason one of the directors at kairos consulting hugh jenkins is a psychotherapist who can help clients sort out personal conflicts family businesses can be extremely successful because the key players are totally dedicated and extra help is available at short notice in busy times but they can also be riven by sibling rivalry rows and differing agendas i have seen families literally tear each other apart says tucker brother feuding with brother grudges held for years or more birth order is important in business hierarchy and tucker says conflicts tend to set in when younger siblings are put in charge of their older brothers and sisters daughters work better with fathers than sons do often kairos works with lawyers financial advisers and wealth management experts to ensure that the business assets pass smoothly from one generation to another keeping it in the family can bring huge perks for sons and daughters foreign travel a company car personal training on the job from the boss a generous expense account all these perks tend to be allocated to the very top executives in companies says katz in a family business however you could be enjoying these at a relatively young age and junior position sometimes being an entrepreneurs son or daughter can be a really cushy number relatively speaking important issues family firms must confront what does the family expect from the business in wealth building regular payouts and employment is there room for a common approach with an increasing number of family members what are the responsibilities of individual members to past current and future generations of the family what rights should family employees have what does the business need in terms of ownership and management is it a realistic longterm business source kairos consulting

exhaustive study to be published next week an analysis of the latest findings from three pioneering studies which have been following the lives of everyone born in england scotland and wales in one compare in detail the results of the three studies it identifies a society more fractured and individualistic but where people at the same time find their success wealth and opportunity dependent on family background to an even greater extent fourteen per cent of men born in were as likely to admit to depression and anxiety in compared with only of the group in for women the differences in the born in at the same age single people too were similarly much more likely to be unhappy with their lot the study coins the phrase sandwiched generation to describe how those born later stay in the family home for longer periods because of the rising cost of housing they also increasingly delay parenthood until their late s and early s at a point when their own parents become in need of support these later cohorts are thus increasingly likely to become sandwiched between the demands of the two adjacent generations and unlikely to enjoy the extended period of freedom from dependency enjoyed by adults in the past the study identifies a stunning transformation in family makeup and the growing fragility of personal relationships ninety per cent of women and of men among the group had become text: would you give up your job if you inherited and if you did carry on working would it change your attitude to work do not be too quick to assume these are hypothetical questions the number of people inheriting money or property is expected to grow substantially over the next few years youve now got secondgeneration homeowners benefiting from inheritances from firstgeneration homeowners says brett afsher of research organisation mintel millions of people will inherit significant amounts over the next few years figures from the official uk household survey suggest there are probably about five million pensioners who own their own homes since the average house is now worth nearly according to the nationwide building society this means billions of pounds of assets can be expected to pass to a fresh generation over the next decade or two inland revenue statistics show the estates of people who had died were notified for probate in but house price inflation and the growth of private savings among the middle classes in the last years are likely to lead to a larger number of legacies of the people who died in about per cent left a legacy and more than half of those left assets worth or more but as people are encouraged to save more for their own needs particularly for retirement housing and education more will die with capital to spare the household survey estimates that there will be million pensioner householders by yvonne bennion of the work foundation believes the inheritance issue could have a profound effect on the workplace and particularly on the relationship between workers and employers there is an effect on motivation she says getting an inheritance can reduce the desire of people to take risks and challenges she believes employers may need to work harder if they want to attract people who have the financial freedom to stay at home there are very interesting consequences for managers what do you have to do to be an employer of choice it may be that they need to take a wider view of flexibility so far employers have tended to introduce flexibility around parental needs but the issue of flexibility now needs to be looked at more broadly whether or not inheritors stay in work it seems that some employers are recognising the need to compete for staff by providing better terms and conditions offering flexibility seems to be commonplace among employers who want to attract older workers bampq the nationwide marks amp spencer and other employers who have a positive attitude to sixtysomethings often offer very flexible arrangements parttime working in particular and other schemes such as leave of up to three months a year and jobsharing it might be that more employers will offer people the opportunity to take a sabbatical says gillian edwards of the human resources consultancy at actuary mercers she also predicts that flexible employment packages will become more widespread allowing workers to design their own deals increasing their holiday entitlement for example and reducing medical insurance benefit mike emmott of the chartered institute of personnel and development believes that authoritarian command and control bosses are going out of fashion and being followed by more respectful and supportive managers jobs that people want to do involve more freedom draw on more parts of their personality and enable them to take more decisions employers might also start improving their pay and benefits levels by for instance introducing golden hellos or simply upping pay alastair hatchett of incomes data services believes some employers might even improve their pension schemes although he does not predict the widespread return of the final salary scheme he says it is more likely that poor money purchase schemes would be enhanced in particular he thinks employers who do not make a contribution into stakeholder pensions might be more likely to do so in future if they felt they to educate workers about the value of good pension plans the inheritance issue is likely to affect only older workers in large numbers but while people in their forties and fifties may now feel coldshouldered by employers this is expected to change a demographic shortage of twentysomethings over the next two decades at least will make older workers more attractive to employers it could be that the issue is already starting to make itself felt many people who have not actually had an inheritance have nevertheless come into a windfall through the explosion in house prices many of those who have traded down and therefore taken out the equity in their old house have had an extra or more to play with these people are contributing to the trends towards leaving large cities forsaking traditional employment downshifting taking up second careers and generally chasing quality of life would you carry on working if you hit the jackpot it is clear that the majority of people who come into very large sums of money are less inclined to work in a survey of winners of m or more in the national lottery camelot found that only per cent of them continued in work and of those per cent moved to a new job lottery winners also tend to be less physically active per cent gained weight as a result of a more sedentary lifestyle however those winning smaller amounts appear to be more likely to continue earning camelots alison boyle says people who win smaller prizes tend to pay off their mortgage go on holiday and throw a party even if they win they tend to feel that they need to keep on working brett afsher of mintel takes the same view about heirs people will continue to save and invest the cost of having children and sending them to university means that a lot of money will dads are the rare fathers who put their childrens happiness above their career they consider themselves very different to their own fathers who traditionally left childcare up to mum twentyfirst text: the number of women who shatter glass ceilings and burst into previously male dominated occupations continues to rise but when it comes to equal pay for doing the same job it is a sad story the reality according to an equal opportunities commission eoc report out this week is that the gap between male and female earnings has hardly closed the equal pay act which removed discrimination between men and women in pay and other terms of their contracts of employment hit the statute books in yet the current eoc figures show that for every that a woman worker earns her male counterpart is paid the gap is even wider for women who have to work parttime to meet their childcare commitments they earn less per hour than men who work fulltime the same gap as years ago whats more the majority of employers polled by eoc said that they have no plans to check whether they pay their female staff fairly the eoc research by the institute for employment studies also reveals that secrecy about pay remains widespread more than a fifth of employers do not allow employees to share information about their pay with colleagues julie mellor chair of the eoc warned that complacency and secrecy were threatening to halt progress on equal pay and urged all employers to review their pay systems for any inbuilt pay bias some practices such as the payment of bonuses and performance related pay were much more common for some occupational groups than others for example a higher proportion of organisations paid performance related bonuses to managers typically male than to mainly female support staff the employing organisations who already carry out the type of thorough equal pay review envisaged by the eoc are thin on the ground the eoc research reveals that only of large employers and of mediumsized employers have actually implemented a pay review the majority of large and of mediumsized employers do not have any plans to conduct a pay review at all ms mellor says the level of complacency and secrecy this research has uncovered is staggering employers have a crucial role to play in tackling unequal pay although some have accepted that responsibility willingly many others still dont seem to have got the message one of the main reasons women are paid less than men is that their jobs are lower down the food chain more than of women workers are in just occupations where they are greatly overrepresented work as sales assistants as secretaries and as nurses none of them highly paid occupations by contrast more than of engineers and technicians much more highly paid professions are men patricia hewitt secretary of state for trade and industry and minister for women said the eoc research reveals a depressing snapshot that shows too many workplaces are still stacked against women fulfiling their true earning potential but it also makes me more determined to keep on working with the eoc employers and unions to close the pay gap the minister pointed to a statutory equal pay questionnaire one of the provisions of the employment bill that is intended to help employment tribunals speed up the resolution of equal pay disputes the questionnaire which comes into force from next month would allow an employee who believes they are not receiving equal pay to request information from their employer on any matter which is or may be relevant to their case this might include details of how much another employee doing similar work or work of equal value earns for a copy of the full report monitoring progress towards pay equality tel eoc helpline or visit wwweocorguk

text: the total cost of having a baby comes as an unexpected shock to almost half of firsttime parents according to a new survey released this week by american express on average it costs almost to cover all the expenses of a babys first year this figure includes prebirth purchases such as maternity wear cot pram and car seat plus daytoday items once the baby is born such as nappies clothing formula milk and food but doesnt include childcare costs and any loss of parental earnings even more will obviously be spent by parents who want designerclad offspring and the latest hitech baby equipment the feel we got by talking to parents and looking at costs was that the real average spend is between at the budget end and at the luxury end said an amex spokesperson some of parents with children under the age of five said their firstborn was more expensive than they had expected and only of respondents said they had budgeted sufficiently for their first child most of those surveyed said that they had had to make lifestyle sacrifices to accommodate unexpected additional baby costs the biggest change had been cutting down on entertainment such as eating out and going to the cinema perhaps an inevitable result of having a young baby as much as because of the costs involved closely followed by buying fewer clothes other lifestyle changes included saying goodbye to expensive foreign holidays or holidaying in the uk instead buying cheaper groceries postponing diy projects and reducing financial contributions to pensions investments and savings a small number of respondents even resorted to a downgrade in the family car to cover the additional costs amexs tip for helping to cope with the impact of baby costs is a rather surprising one put your familys household spending on to a credit card which provides cashback rather than a a debit card however this only makes sense if you have the discipline to pay off your bill in full each month and avoid any interest charges among cashback cards the american express blue card and the capital one circle card provide the best return each giving a cashback on everything you spend other practical ways of coping with baby costs include plan ahead and save as much as possible in advance during the pregnancy when both parents are still working keep the money in an accessible nonotice bank or building society account check out the best interest rates in jobs amp moneys best buy tables or on theguardiancommoney draw up a baby list and suggest practical items you really need when friends and family ask what gift they can buy for your new baby this saves money and avoids receiving unwanted drycleanonly designer threads and mountains of stuffed toys accept offers of handmedowns and buy secondhand clothing toys and certain equipment local branches of the charity national childbirth trust nct regularly run nearly new sales where you can buy baby and childrens clothes and equipment at much reduced prices straight from their owners the only items not sold are cot mattresses and car seats which should ideally be bought new for a baby nct sales also offer parents a chance to recoup some money spent previously on new items by selling them on the charity takes a commission on what you sell for details of your near est nct branch and nearly new sales across the uk for call the charity on or visit wwwnctpregnancyandbabycarecom also worth a look is online vendor wwwkidsgloriouskidscouk which offers gently worn secondhand maternity and childrens clothing toys and accessories if you are using disposable nappies supermarket own brand labels cost less and its cheaper to buy in bulk but you can really cut costs and prevent waste if you join the of parents who opt for reusable nappies according to the womens environmental network wwwwenorguk which says that savings from using home laundered nappies for a single child can amount to for advice contact the real nappy project at wen on nappieswenorguk the cost of formula milk makes breastfeeding a much cheaper option if it works for you and once you start weaning you can save by pureeing your own baby food rather than buying expensive packets and jars before buying nonessential items such as baby bouncers borrow one if possible to see if its worth the outlay take a tip from parents about the things you can do without travel consultant kerry cipriano says that despite planning ahead and saving up before the birth of her first child luca now aged two and a half she was still taken aback by the costs involved overall i think we spent more than in preparation for luca and during his first year she says some of that such as doing up and equipping the nursery wed saved up for while i was pregnant and still working full time but it was the ongoing costs afterwards that came as a surprise babies grow so fast that i seemed to be buying new clothes all the time i must have spent or so in the first year i was also unable to breastfeed for long so buying formula milk was a large expense other unexpected costs were the price of mother and baby group activities such as swimming and tumble tots which cost around looking back ms cipriano who lives in huby north yorkshire realises there are some things she could have done without i only used the baby bath about twice and never used the bottle warmer id bought the baby carrier was also a waste of money be cause luca hated it she says on the other hand other expensive luxuries like a battery operated baby swing costing were worth their weight in gold two minutes in that and he was asleep so it was a great investment practical presents from relatives saved ms cipriano some money but a dearth of nearly new shops or sales in her area meant she had to buy most things new weve coped with the costs by things like cutting down on holidays and going out a lot less than we used to she says i also try to budget carefully and make the most of cash back and loyalty cards like the boots advantage card which gives me points when i buy nappies that i can redeem on future shopping the birth of her second child daughter issey seven weeks ago has had far less of a financial impact on the family so far weve bought hardly anything new for issey ms cipriano says weve recycled the pram cot and other equipment and shes wearing handmedowns from a friends text: as a fulltime working mother i think i am one of the many who juggle to ensure that our children are happy our families are happy and that we are fulfilled in our jobs in the knowledge that the money is coming in or that our career is progressing nicely it seems to me that much of the work culture in the uk is based on first in last out we never cease in our quest to impress the boss having children made me see that and i changed i still meet my targets and more but i dont hang around the office making coffee or chatting to pass the time when i arrive at work i work then i leave to go home knowing that i have performed well made a difference i feel people wondering how i manage to pluck up the courage to leave first but i dont flinch except at a few weak moments i have to remind myself that i have done the days work and that it will continue tomorrow and staying another hour or two will not change that on my way home i think about my next shift feeding bathing clothing reading and much more a fouryearold and an monthold harder than the day job then after six or seven hours sleep its time to start running again tactics are there to get the children to the nurseries on time switch again time for the office job thoughts run to the series of events i must undertake to ensure i am successful today but at oclock i have learned to stop because i know if i dont ill just go on and on and on like the others work is very important for money for job satisfaction and for my sanity but its not the only important thing in life and life is not eternal when we truly realise this we will learn to balance our lives so that we can begin to enjoy and value them shazia

isnt thomass dad he is a nanny a male nanny obviously cutely termed a manny btectrained and in his third nannying position at he commutes from hastings to care for thomas in beckenham kent plus another boy of a similar age its much freer than a structured office job he says and youre getting to see children develop and grow you bond with them definitely i dont think im special or better than a female nanny everyone has their own approach but im unusual friends laughed when i started studying nursery nursing on my course i was the only man among women somehow i coped although its still rare to find men on traditional nannying courses attitudes are changing in the united states parents are employing young mannies sometimes to care for babies but more often as active role models to coax junior away from the tv and the computer from rollerblading buddies to summer surf mannies these are the big brothers who are always willing to play to boot a football in the driving rain largely text: first there were the baby boomers then there was thatchers children after them came generations x and y and now now apparently we have the diy generation marketers love inventing new terms so they can pigeon hole people but while in the past they have tended to do so in cultural terms giving the groups sexy labels such as generation x they now appear keen on more utilitarian pursuits by using labels to define goups in financial terms cue the diy generation research by marks amp spencer financial services is the latest attempt to conjure up a new demographic group its research has identified the diy generation as todays to yearolds facing a future squeeze on their finances the research found that members of this generation more than its predecessors will have to fend for themselves financially and should expect to see less in the way of inherited wealth yet according to the research twothirds of the group were deluding themselves by relying on some form of inheritance to cushion them against future financial difficulties not that long ago banking on an inheritance to boost personal wealth was impossible for most people for a long time it was the preserve of only the very seriously rich but all that changed as personal wealth grew dramatically in the second half of the thcentury it was the resulting rapid growth in inherited wealth that led former prime minister john major to say in a famous speech that wealth was cascading down the generations however there is mounting evidence that the tide is beginning to turn and that the inheritance pot is on the verge of drying up in short the money which would once have been set aside to be passed on to the next generation is out of necessity being used to fund retirement as life expectancy continues to rise retirement income is increasingly stretched to the limit savings and home equity are dipped into more and more to help with the costs of a long retirement and sometimes with expensive long term care with life expectancy predicted to grow even further this leaves retirees with less money to pass on and diyers with further pressure to fend for themselves and perhaps even subsidise their parents if there is one thing we know for certain about the future it is that life expectancy is going up warns donna bradshaw of independent financial advisers fiona price and partners younger people need to realise that inheritance is not an entitlement people can expect to be retired for around years now and i would advise the retired to make the most of it rather than worry about leaving money to their children people really are going to have to take more responsibility for themselves and save more as people live longer and longterm care costs become an issue it just doesnt make sense to rely on an inheritance the diy generation could become stuck between a rock and a hard place the mamps research predicts not only are they in more debt than any previous generation but diyers will face the added problem that the times in life when people traditionally save more will no longer mean the same for them a combination of paying for student debts for longer taking on larger mortgages and having children later in life will mean there will be few financially commitmentfree stages in a diyers life the older generation may be struggling to fund their retirement but the outlook for the younger generation is even worse says alan rensch of mamps financial services the stages in our lives where we traditionally squirrel away savings are being squeezed people will need to dip into the assets such as property to make up for the shortfall of their own retirement savings rather than passing them on to the next generation he adds this will leave a new diy generation who must adopt the savings mentality as early as possible if they are to face the financial challenges ahead and not be disappointed in old age but there is another threat looming for baby boomers and diyers alike soaring house prices have pushed thousands more people into the inheritance tax bracket it is not uncommon for a property to now exceed the threshold at which inheritance tax kicks in some m homes are already there according the halifax so unless they can find a way to dodge the tax retired people hoping to leave a decent inheritance could see a large chunk of it disappear and it is anyones guess what will happen when the diyers finally get to retire baby boomers earning their name because of the sheer volume of children born after the second world war baby boomers became synonymous with hippiedom flower power and the first summer of love they were also the first generation to benefit from a breakdown of class barriers spurred by wider higher education opportunities and the opening of text: some promising developments are in the wind in the long struggle for parents to win tax exemption for child care last month paymaster general dawn primarolo launched a government consultation paper on the issue consultation closes on may too late to have any influence on this years budget but an indication that next years budget may bring good news what was significant was that the paper was launched at the royal london hospital the nhs has been busy encouraging the establishment of workplace creches in nhs trusts and unlike some government schemes this is well on the way to delivery its purpose is to encourage health professionals who have left their jobs to have children to return in establishing better childcare provision however the nhs came up against the nub of the problem healthcare requires shift work and the availability of ninetofive childcare is of limited use to a nurse who starts work at am so in tandem with creche facilities nhs trusts are also being encouraged to set up childcare coordinators to give advice on longterm and emergency childcare provision there is a financial issue here too while workplace creches are not a taxable benefit so called childcare vouchers the provision an employer might make towards a child minder or on a slightly grander scale a nanny are not the government line on this continues to soften the blair administration has been very parentfriendly not least in introducing tax exemption for workplace creches now it is minded to allow employers to make other forms of childcare such as company approved childminders available tax free this is more likely to be of interest to public sector employers rather than the private sector the metropolitan police is one employer wrestling with the problem of providing childcare for shiftworkers the government cannot quite bring itself to allow full tax exemption for parents who would prefer to approve their own childminders but the idea is under consideration and the tide seems to be moving that way

text: parents of children under six or of disabled youngsters under will have the right to apply to work flexibly from next month this means they will be able to request a change in the hours or the times they work or to be able to do so from home at the same time the government will increase and extend maternity leave and pay and introduce new rights to paid adoption and pater nity leave all these changes which come into force on april will be the sternest test yet of employers commitment to helping staff achieve a satisfactory worklife balance they will also raise fundamental questions about the relationship between companies and their employees and about the future of work itself it is a wakeup call to employers there is a definite trend towards people wanting to have a life and be more than a wage slave says bill quirke head of synopsis a consultancy specialising in business communication the legislation is speeding up something that has been happening for the past five years the question is how do you encourage flexibility without making it a problem to the business the new legislation will enable parents to ask to work flexibly though there is no automatic right and employers have the discretion to turn down their requests in order to make a request you must have a child under six or a disabled child under have worked continuously with your employer for weeks by the date the application make the application no later than two weeks before the childs sixth birthday have responsibility for the childs upbringing not be an agency worker or a member of the armed forces you must make the application in writing and only one request a year is allowed if your employer agrees to allow you to work flexibly you must accept a permanent change to your terms and conditions this is vital because it may mean taking a pay cut or adversely affecting your employers business so you need to think carefully about the implications your employer must arrange to meet you with days of your formal written request to discuss your plans two weeks later you must be told the result of your request and either when your new working pattern will start or why your application has been turned down the new rules should make it much easier for parents who are trying to juggle work and childcare says peter thompson of henley management college there is evidence that a high percentage of people who ring in sick do so because their children are ill but they feel uncomfortable about telling their employer thompson says the new legislation will give parents the option to change their working hours to fit around school hours for example coming in at am and leaving at pm and doing the rest of their work in the evening when the children are in bed one aspect parents need to be aware of is that it is no good trying to work from home while looking after children you need to put in place the same childcare as though you were going out to work he says some big employers such as lloyds tsb nationwide prudential and ibm have anticipated these changes and already put in policies to help their staff work more flexibly quirke of synopsis believes employers should be looking to use flexibility working as a way of recruiting and retaining staff rather than as an administrative headache when you are short of people who possess the right skills this is a way of encouraging people to join the workforce he says quirke has tips for wouldbe flexible workers who are thinking of approaching their employer think about why flexi working is important to you identify what is valuable about what you do and the way you do it communicate this to your boss in a formal request think about how it will affect your colleagues and boss and take this into account when you putyour proposal together while flexible working is fine in theory parents may find that in practice the rhetoric falls short it is one thing for an organisation to have a flexible working policy and quite another for that culture to have filtered down to line managers says professor malcolm higgs at henley management college the company can talk about its flexible working policy yet line managers who dont like things to change can exert subtle pressure the smart employer should see the new legislation as an opportunity not a problem says dr maria yapp business psychologist with xancam consulting the more enlightened employers are not thinking what can i squeeze out of this person but see their staff as an investment the more control you give people over their own lives and destiny the less stress they suffer

text: in cashpoints today twothirds of women are on below average pay columnist marianne curphey on compensation culture dr work answers your questions march twothirds of women on below average income union leaders today stepped up their campaign to close the pay gap between men and women after a new report showed that almost twothirds of adult women compared with of adult men are on a below average income story in full what it means for you when asked to comment on the depressing statistics released by the trades union congress tuc this week tuc general secretaryelect brendan barber said the most effective way to lift women out of a life of poverty would be to eradicate the gender pay gap to allow women to earn a decent wage for the work they do thirty years after the equal pay act the gender pay gap remains a reality in the uk by the age of male graduates are already earning an average more than their female contemporaries on a likeforlike basis and across the age groups that gap rises to so why is the pay gap still with us and what is the government planning to do about it julie mellor chairperson of the equal opportunities commission lays some of the blame at the door of the british culture of secrecy about pay she believes that transparency about pay and bonuses is essential in every part of the labour market without that transparency there is a danger that factors other than performance could influence the rewards people receive she has high hopes of the new equal pay questionnaire for employees who suspect they are being paid unfairly which is due to be published on april alongside this a change in the law in april means that employees can discover what colleagues doing the same job are paid without having to go to a tribunal a first move in the text: ted heath was in downing street slade were in the charts and there was a whole decade of political turbulence and dodgy fashion just around the corner it was more than years ago way back in that the equal pay act gave women the legal right to be paid the same as men sounds like a different world doesnt it and in many ways it is for over years the gap between mens and womens pay has been slowly but steadily shrinking yet a recent report from the equal opportunities commission eoc shows that unfair pay is not as outdated as we might have hoped last year almost years after merry xmas everybody was played for the very first time the gap widened again even without the recent bad news quarter of a century after the equal pay act women still havent caught up in the pay stakes the average hourly wage for a working man remains higher than it is for a woman or to put it another way a woman working full time earns just of her male colleagues salary for parttime workers of all working women are in parttime jobs that figure sinks to the pay gap will cost a woman with average qualifications during her lifetime for a lowskilled woman with two children the figure is closer to half a million the government had hoped that a mixture of initiatives in particular the introduction of the minimum wage would have a positive impact on wage differences why is it then that the situation has actually worsened for the first time in so many years according to a report by income data services the change is due to the high pay rises given last year to senior workers the vast majority of whom are male substantial jumps in pay for the top of male employees has pulled the overall male average upwards thus creating the growing difference it is hard to bear but its not quite a tragedy and in fact the statistic conceals some rather better news across the remaining of the workforce womens average hourly earnings actually grew at a faster rate than mens if it werent for the rises given to the most highlypaid men the gap should actually have continued its gradual shrinking but dont break out the babycham just yet with women making up exactly half the workforce why is it that the proportion of female top workers is small enough for changes in that sector to have such an impact and why is it that with space hoppers and the threeday week consigned to the dustbin of history an anachronism like the gender pay gap is still with us the governments equal pay taskforce outlined three main reasons behind the wage imbalance the first is what they call occupational segregation women in laymans terms tend to have lower paid jobs even in male secretaries and female it consultants are the exception figures released this february show that women still make up of employees in personal services and just of managers senior officials and professionals the second is the unequal impact of family responsibilities it is still more likely to be mum not dad who shoulders most of the childcare a trend that will be hard to reverse as long as dads job is the more lucrative stepping out of the labour market even briefly means that many women come back to work with reduced earning power and severely compromised prospects lastly there is straightforward pay discrimination though given what julie mellor chair of the eoc calls the british culture of secrecy about pay it is anything but straightforward mellor believes that transparency about pay and bonuses is essential in every part of the labour market without that transparency there is a danger that factors other than performance could influence the rewards people receive she has high hopes of the new equal pay questionnaire for employees who suspect they are being paid unfairly which is due to be published on april produced by the eoc the questionnaire should help resolve pay disputes and make the costly complex and confrontational tribunal process considerably swifter and hopefully unnecessary the confederation of british industry cbi on the other hand feels such moves need to be handled carefully the cbi considers unequal pay to be a serious issue but it feels that unfair discrimination makes up only a small part of the pay gap it welcomes the practical equal pay review tool recently launched on the eocs website but sees any legislation as unnecessarily intrusive and cumbersome susan anderson director of human resources policy at the cbi says we need to give more choices to women who are trying to balance work with family responsibilities that is far more sensible than imposing ineffective legislation on all employers to curb the discriminatory practices of a few unfortunately however it may not be just a few who are discriminating in the governments equal pay taskforce found that direct discrimination accounts for approximately half the difference in mens and womens pay denise kingsmill who headed the taskforce recommended a legislative approach to the problem and was promptly asked to perform another review with a specific remit to examine and report on possible nonlegislative proposals she now feels that voluntary audits will work but has stressed that the progress of the private sector in carrying out such audits really ought to be monitored with a view to considering the need for legislation on laggards at a future date such equivocal phrasing does not seem to herald radical change particularly since as a recent article in the guardian pointed out of businesses are perfectly satisfied with their pay systems as well they might be an eoc report published in january this year showed that only of nonexecutive directors in uk listed companies are women perhaps it is not surprising that the establishment should be satisfied with a system that protects its own so effectively figures like these make very miserable reading the fight however is far from over this year the government is bringing in new legislation to tackle gender discrimination lord lesters equality bill of recommendations was recently passed by the house of lords more immediately flexible working regulations will come into force from april meaning employers will have a legal duty to consider requests for flexible working from employees who are parents of young children paternity and maternity leave arrangements will also be improved encouraging mum and dad and their employers to look at family responsibilities as having a more general claim of course closing the gender pay gap requires a major shift in attitudes that will only develop over time however while its inevitable that christmas will see slades vintage classic making yet another comeback at office parties everywhere perhaps one thing we can avoid next year is a repeat of s retro statistics that really would make it a merry christmas
