text: when redundancy strikes the nanny is the first casualty take sally thirtysomething and a successful conference organiser with two children aged four and six laura sallys nanny looked after the children three days a week while sally worked at her central london office then bam sallys company folded and within hours laura was given her notice i felt bad about it but the simple fact is that i wasnt earning any more so i couldnt afford to shell out the a month that laura was costing me says sally i decided to take a couple of months off and then look around for freelance work these days ive got some projects but im earning nothing like my previous salary so a nanny is a luxury i cant afford we have a slovakian au pair i pay her a week and she looks after the children after school and for a couple of evenings while we go out shes a lot cheaper than laura and i dont have to pay tax or ni contributions on her earnings in south london where sally lives playgrounds buzz with eastern european accents as au pairs take over where nannies once reigned economic uncertainty is forcing families to cut back on childcare and the easiest thing to do is to swap the qualified nanny for an unqualified but enthusiastic au pair who will help out around the home for a fraction of a nannys salary no surprise then that for nannies times are lean the pay of the average london livein fell by per cent last year against an inflation rate of per cent and many have to search weeks before landing a job it might not sound too serious until you set it against last years stories that nannies were demanding their own flat car clothing allowance and private healthcare in addition to salaries of up to carla shimeld editor of the listings magazine simply childcare says if youre a nanny looking for a job at the moment its quite a shock to realise how different things suddenly are shimeld says todays situation is partly the result of the rise in nannys wages which allows many to stay put rather than moving on but she also believes that the flood of girls from eastern europe has changed the job situation for homegrown nannies girls are coming in on au pair visas but theyre keen to earn as much money as possible so theyre a lot more willing to do domestic duties if it means extra cash she says the influx of eastern european au pairs is also having a knockon effect on childcare agencies alastair mcatee who runs the cheshire agency says hes decided not to place nannies any more there just isnt the demand its all happening in the au pair market he says mcatee has set up an au pair website wwwfindanaupaircom and business is booming theres a huge demand for au pairs because a lot of parents out there need help often its a mum and dad who are desperate to get out to work but a nanny is way out of their price range but finding an au pair doesnt necessarily mean keeping her for any length of time au pairs are like cats if theyre happy they will stay but if not they will soon find another home and i have a lot of trouble getting through to people that you have to treat an au pair as one of the family theyre not just a hired help says mcatee childcare campaigners also point out that au pairs arent quality child carers certainly theyre not recommended for babies and very young children or to be in sole charge for long periods of time but that attitude in itself represents what others see as a failure to grasp the complexity of the childcare issue shimeld says the government in particular is completely unrealistic about real needs childcare policy tends to concentrate on nurseries nannies and eighttosix care for preschoolers real families change and they change very quickly soon youve got children at school and others at nursery and afterschool clubs to get to and its all very complicated she says nurseries do clearly have their place and in the current uncertain economic climate they can sometimes represent particularly for a onechild family a more affordable option than a nanny jo philips a designer in north london says ive been trying to find a nursery place for my oneyearold and so far three ive contacted have told me that i can go on the waiting list but they wouldnt hold out a lot of hope when the forms arrived i was surprised to see that they didnt ask for the babys age they asked for the estimated date of delivery clearly you have to plan ahead better than ive done childminders are another cheaper option but they again are in short supply mandi whitington a childminder in canterbury says she had to turn away six children in just two weeks over christmas they all phoned within about days of each other and i just didnt have the vacancies its very difficult for parents they get the list of childminders in the area and then they start phoning round and its just one no after another a lot of the people who phone are mothers going back to work after maternity leave they tend to be demoralised by the lack of vacancies for babies and they often say that if they cant find childcare theyll have to give up work many parents feel childminders who are usually mothers themselves and who offer homebased care are the best option for babies and very young children but current regulations prevent registered childminders from having more than one baby under one unless theyre twins this says whitington is unnecessary sometimes youre having to turn away a sixmonthold because youve already got a monthold it doesnt make sense because their needs are different and the older baby will soon have his or her first birthday anyway according to oliver black director of tinies childcare which accounts for about per cent of the uk childcare market the bottom line is that the industry is still far too fragmented and issues like tax are still to be tackled people have to pay for childcare out of net income which means childcarers have to keep charges low if the tax incentives were deep enough and broad enough it would mean salaries could go up it would mean nurseries could recruit staff more easily and pay them better few nursery chains are making money at the moment although we all know the government included that this is a huge growth area and that parents are crying out for better provision and more choice in the sort of childcare they use he says reaping the benefits from april the new child tax credit and working tax credit will help supplement the incomes of parents families with incomes of up to will be eligible for the child tax credit which replaces the childrens tax credit this will be worth up to a year to families on low incomes with several children but the majority will receive a year those with at least one child under one year old will get a bigger payment the credit will be paid directly to the main carer and can be spent in any way that the carer chooses the working tax credit which replaces the working families tax credit is designed to top up wages for those on low incomes and will include an element to cover part of a familys childcare costs it will pay up to per cent of eligible childcare costs up to a maximum of a week for one child equal to a credit of a week and a week for two or more children equal to a credit of up to a week complete an application by calling or visiting wwwmoneymummycouk single parents can get help with childcare costs if they join the new deal for lone parents while training or looking for work more at wwwnewdealgovuk all fouryearolds are currently entitled to a free nursery place and from this will be extended to all threeyearolds more at wwwchildcarelinkgovuk one in employers provides some help with childcare in the form of allowances vouchers a subsidised nursery or an advice line large organisations such as local authorities and organisations with lots of women employees such as banks tend to offer the most smaller employers though can sometimes help by being flexible about working hours dos and donts do think about asking your nanny to set up a personal service company so she can reduce her and so your tax and ni bills a nanny with her own company can set the salary she pays herself through her company to be lower than the amount she charges for her work do stick with a nanny if you have two or more children including one or more underfives nannies can be good value for several kids do think about a nursery if your child is twoplus and needs more input many nurseries double as nurseries for twoandahalf year olds and up do investigate taking on an au pair if you have room in your home and are around a lot of the time eg working from home do think about reciprocal agreements with other parents if youre working parttime maybe you could look after a friends child while she goes to work and viceversa dont put your baby into a nursery if you think youll soon be having another two children in a nursery isnt usually costeffective dont take on an au pair if what you really need is eighttosix sole charge childcare dont rule out a childminder without looking into the options some areas have more childminders available than others and they do represent good value for money

text: the baby boomer generation is still breaking demographic records a large proportion of them are seeing their teenage children off to college and then splitting up a recent report from the economic and social research council shows that the number of separating couples in their late s and early s has doubled in the past years making them the largest single divorcing group a full of children over experienced their parents divorce in so what is it about this stage of life that prompts a parting of ways clearly those who believed that an early split would be damaging and unfair to the family suddenly have a choice the point at which children leave home creates a natural break you are face to face alone over the kitchen table explains gina who left home shortly after her youngest daughter went to university suddenly there is no buffer between you and him there is no mother role to hide behind and you think this is it for the rest of my life he wants something from me and i dont think i can give it such an urge to leave can come as a complete shock to a partner and even to the person who is leaving i am amazed at the speed of these breakdowns one relate counsellor told me it is as if the marriage has been masked in some way by the busy allconsuming role of mother and father working parents household organisers with no time to think once the last child is gone the routine and the role goes too and the couple are left to review what is left but there can be no mistaking the enormity of such a move sally fisher learned of her husbands intention to leave just days after her son went away to college of course i knew things would be different we never discussed it but i had assumed we would have the time and energy for all the things we had enjoyed in our year marriage but he clearly had other plans the shock was devastating a physical pain like being aerated by one of those garden spike machines i fight the desperate sense of so what was all that about then by reminding myself we have a wonderful son out of it but the sense of betrayal and worthlessness has made me wonder if i put too much into marriage and mothering if it ends in ashes like this penny mansfield from one plus one the social research organisation that monitors couple relationships agrees that when the last child leaves home it can be a challenging time for many couples many people do say i want something for myself now not as a parent or a provider but for me it saddens me that partners often completely fail to recognise the urgency of demands like this over and over again i see people refusing to change and resisting when partners say they have had enough now and so often when their spouse has gone off and found someone who will begin on a new life adventure they say if only i had known i would have given it a go opportunities for the people whom mansfield describes as young middleaged are tremendous parents have never been hipper as the last child leaves home they are often feeling fit youthful and ready for the adventures of the next years sociologist anthony giddens has written widely on second chances in life and sees divorce in this light divorce is an option it is no longer a disgrace i can remember one aunt when i was a child who was divorced and singled out to sit alone in a corner with a small sherry today we accept that divorce can be a mechanism for a fresh beginning something new and exciting and the disapproval from young people is so much less and when kids leave home they do negotiate a new relationship with their parents anyway they often say they get to know their parents for the first time certainly the censure was gone for me reflects robert a yearold who left home only two months after his youngest child went to university i had been silently fearful of any terrible scenes suddenly there was the prospect of doing my own thing without the reproachful glances over the breakfast table the prospect of freedom was heady stuff and i went for it probably in a very selfish way but i had to do it gina too remembers her first flush of life on her own as a real exhilaration its ironic but the unpredictability after a life of such order and organisation was just fabulous mansfield points out that older divorced people now feel they can swim in the exciting waters of singledom alongside younger people our society especially in the urban setting is much more fluid and open to single life than it was we are less willing to condemn those who divorce not to be married in your s is not the unusual phenomenon it once was laura telfer a relate counsellor for years agrees that the split when the children have gone can be very appealing there is definitely a susceptible time when the children leave home when all possibilities seem open but it does not make the unexpected desertion any easier what can be an exciting venture for one partner is invariably a painful grieving episode for other family members children watch appalled as their family that secure and safe place that survived all their childhoods is swiftly dismantled bronwen hipkin whose marriage ended after years resents the label of failure how can a relationship that has nurtured children almost into adulthood be viewed as anything but a success i honestly believe that marriages have their allotted life span and some come to the end of their natural life i really dont think that separating couples who have done a good job bringing up their kids should beat themselves up over this but robert who left home so abruptly acknowledges the devastation his departure caused i have not escaped the fury of the children they could not forgive me for what i did and frankly i have seen them very little since then they are so enraged our meetings turn into bitterly reproachful tirades at the moment our only relationship seems to consist of the handover of the cheque gina who feels that she powered her exit from marriage with a potent mixture of raging emotion and rebellion from the domestic role also has regrets the rush of excitement fades and then it is too late to go back words cannot express the physical feelings of loss and grief you experience and it goes on as the children get older the graduation ceremonies and weddings are all flashpoints for conflict and difficulty you cannot help thinking how it might have been the joy you would have felt at witnessing these events together it suddenly feels completely wrong to be there alone or with someone who is nothing to do with your child i felt i left for adventure and freedom and doing things my own way but i also took on a lifetime of being brave for the childrens sake trying to be calm and skilful about the break being diplomatic about his new wife it is a constant struggle and when i know how easy it could have been and how there will never be that person to grow old with who was with me in the first part of my life i feel tragic

text: women graduates are more likely than nongraduates to remain childless throughout their lives the office for national statistics said yesterday in a report which may explain the decline in britains birth rate the governments statisticians found that nine in every women with a university degree or other higher education qualification had no children by the end of their childbearing years compared with six in every nongraduates graduate mothers who delayed having children until after tended to have them in quick succession and their experience of higher education made little difference to the size of their families at any given age of childbearing mothers with a higher qualification were more likely than those without to have another child and were more likely to do so quickly but of those with a university degree or teaching or nursing qualification remained childless compared with of those without the result came from research into the experience of women born in england and wales between and who are coming to the end of their childbearing years about one in six of that age group achieved a higher qualification compared with one in three in the current generation of school leavers steve smallwood one of the authors of the report said it could not be proved that the expansion of higher education had caused the decline in national fertility rates over this period but it was possible that there was a link if it were so the governments plan to increase the proportion of the population with experience of higher education to could further depress the birth rate and contribute to the expected decline in the uk population after he said the relationship between education and fertility is complex a higher education may delay childbearing and increase the opportunity cost of having children but it also increases income the women graduates may have more to spend on children and that could result in having more of them the ons also published its uk population projections based on data from the census it expects the population to grow from m to m by nearly less than previously estimated its longer term projections suggest that the population will peak at nearly m in and then gradually decline to below m in the population of pensioners will exceed the number of children for the first time in by there will be about pensioners and children for every people of working age the figures for marriages in england and wales show there were in fewer than in and down on the number of religious ceremonies dropped by between and and the number of civil weddings fell by in the same period the average marrying age for single men rose from years in to in and for single women it increased from to the ons found that teenage girls were twice as likely to give birth if they were themselves the daughters of teenage mothers nearly twothirds of the uks population increase over the next years up by m to m will be caused by immigration according to the study

text: as a result of happy circumstance my friend rebecca is in the enviable position of being the breadwinner in her household while her man looks after the children so how is it she asks me that at oclock on a weekday morning i find myself looking after the children while my husband goes for a run rebecca and i talk frequently on the phone as i am in a similar situation my husband left his job just as i got a new contract to work from home i had no idea how it was going to work but he was enthusiastic he had put our first baby to bed every night for the first two years while i worked late so its not as if he was new to childcare we decided to give it a try in the early days of the arrangement my working day was limited to the new babys nap times sure my husband was running the household and doing childcare he was taking our twoyearold to the zoo to the beach to the aquarium they went shopping together and had a great time it was marvellous except that he was looking after one child and we have two to manage two children at the same time he assured me was beyond the capabilities of normal people our children both under three are probably at the most demanding age between working at a computer and caring for toddlers there is absolutely no question as to which is the more arduous much of the time my husband feels im shirking when i sneak off to my study to squeeze in an hours work and because i know how hard his job is i am easily dissuaded from going up to my study i cant just sit at my desk if i hear howling from downstairs either their howls or his a sensible person would have rented an office so she wouldnt be in the house but it seemed an unnecessary expense and quite frankly i dont think the arrangement would have lasted five minutes forced to care for both children for an eighthour day my husband would have rebelled i often find myself thinking if you were a woman you would just get on with it grumbles rebecca how many women doing gruelling days with two or three children would love to say i cant do it you have to lend a hand but of course he isnt a woman and there are not many men who would do as much as he does psychologist janet riebstein who lectures on families and relationships says that negotiation is the key the only way to make it work is to treat parenting like a business you need routines and clarity you need to say you are responsible from four till six or three days a week you are in charge if you change the boundaries and have no clarity all hell breaks loose the kids decide whos in charge and that becomes the routine my male friends who work from home dont seem to have any problem negotiating themselves a full working day nick makes his wife furious because although he is in the house he is never available to help with the children linda whose husband alex works at home while she looks after their three children expects him to go to his study and stay there till until he made an office in a small outbuilding in the garden they were getting right on top of each other we both like our space she says but you know what writers are like theyll do almost anything rather than write he used to come down every five minutes and make a cup of tea interrupting my day now hes got his work space its much better for us both alex is only required to help out with their three small children in a dire emergency and even that he admits he does with reluctance i just cant cope its partly resentment as its not my job from the fathers point of view there is very little to recommend fulltime parenting you will never get any credit from anyone as a man looking after children says frank who works parttime and does threequarters of the childcare you will get a lot of hostility the only credit you are likely to get is from other mothers who are going to use your example to complain to their husbands and thus alienate all your friends work colleagues will look at you with a mix of pity and disdain i have stood outside school gates for years without anyone speaking to me ever my husband admits he sometimes feels like a cipher with no value or purpose most fulltime parents both men and women feel that way at some time especially those whose career has been achievementoriented when you are in the thick of temper tantrums with children who refuse to eat hit each other and are still running downstairs at pm you never feel you are doing a good job as well as losing status the fulltime father gives up the benefits such as money to spend on himself and a room of his own with limited space only one person in the family is going to get a study most men caring for the children full time see it as taking time out from their career says dr riebstein author of staying alive a family memoir bloomsbury it is so much less socially acceptable for a man to have no career path at all whereas it is a choice that a woman makes the social devaluing of a man without a work role can come between a man and his partner over time it can create a problem dealing with resentment from the fulltime parent isnt easy when you know you couldnt hack it yourself coming back from business trips is a nightmare says rebecca i am always in the doghouse for a day or two he never ever asks me what i did who i saw was it interesting while im away he phones me every day to tell me how little the children have slept and how often theyve been sick every man i meet in the course of business who asks about my home arrangements is amazed you have a very understanding husband said one man whose wife divorced him because his work took precedence over his family i bet he thinks youre off having a great time i do consider myself and more importantly my children extremely fortunate in having their father looking after them this time together will lay down the foundation of their relationships for the rest of their lives since i have a flexible working timetable we have to work at creating a structured personal arrangement well probably have got it right by the time my husband gets another job some find the separation of work and family life essential but it would not work in our house and maybe i would not want it to sometimes im playing with the baby before her midday nap and i think about how i used to spend all day in an office looking at my childrens photos instead of tickling their feet for a parent working from home is ideal in many ways but it is easy to spoil by failing to negotiate with ones partner over time and yes that includes time for running

text: almost a quarter of a century has passed since the specials were number one in the charts with a song that began youve done too much much too young youre married with a kid when you should be having fun with me referring to the kid in question singer terry hall went on aint he cute no he aint hes just another product of the welfare state strip away the macho posturing and the specials were as so often reflecting an aspect of life in their home city of coventry twentythree years on there are still plenty of mothers in coventry and elsewhere who are school age or not much more every year some teenagers in england and wales have a baby a few of these are married but are not and while attitudes towards marriage and sex may have changed since teenage mothers still feel looked down on by the rest of society researchers from coventry university have unearthed evidence of that after interviewing more than mothers who became pregnant before they were well before in some cases the researchers have produced two reports one on housing and the other on pre and postnatal experiences and although there was anxiety not to stereotype young mothers the reports point out that low selfesteem is rife rightly or wrongly the young mothers feel they are being judged by housing and health professionals as well as by older mothers on antenatal courses that in turn is dissuading them from accessing services to which they are entitled the bottom line is that this is impacting on their children and it could be putting their health at risk says gayle letherby deputy director of the universitys centre for social justice and spokeswoman for the research team coventry primary care trust pct has already taken on board recommendations from the first report about changing the design of its semisupported housing accommodation where mothers with nowhere else to go can stay with help from support workers until they can find a permanent address as a result of the second report the pct is drawing up a training programme for health professionals who work with young mothers midwives health visitors nurses and doctors are expected to take part we want to challenge the stereotypical views that many of them admit to having when dealing with this group says kirsty reid teenage pregnancy support coordinator we also want to involve young parents and perhaps challenge their view of health professionals letherby believes that misunderstandings are at the heart of the issue as the second report says communication between young women and health professionals is affected by stereotypes on both sides some young women having internalised the dominant negative discourse of teenage pregnancy and motherhood expect to encounter judgmental attitudes and some health professionals are suspicious and critical of young pregnant women on the issue of smoking during pregnancy for instance a health professional is quoted as saying you ask them if theyve given up and they say yes but you can smell it on them some will say theyve cut down but whether they have or not this against a comment from a young mother they always ask you if you drink or smoke she says but if you say no they stare like they dont believe you anyway so whats the point in asking ive never smoked in my life but its like they think oh youre a pregnant teenager you must smoke politically teenage pregnancy is receiving more attention than ever before past claims that teenagers were getting pregnant to acquire a council flat have given way to what appears to be a more constructive approach from new labour letherby however is critical of the continuing projection of the nuclear family as the ideal and the consequent linking of all teenage pregnancies with social exclusion like older women she says sometimes these pregnancies are planned and sometimes theyre accidents in our experience though the vast majority of babies are definitely wanted is there a danger that she could be seen to be encouraging promiscuity at a time when britain continues to have more teenage pregnancies than any other country in western europe its important that young women dont feel pressurised into relationships they dont want and have access to the right contraception letherby says at the same time its important that those who become pregnant are not stigmatised were not supporting promiscuity were telling it like it is the specials would have said much the same halfway house where children become parents lois has eight gcses of grade c and above she also has a monthold baby called abbie conceived when lois was and staying at her aunts house in yorkshire i didnt tell my parents until i was five months pregnant she says my mums ok now but theres no way i could have lived at home at that time so when lois moved back to coventry she stayed with the parents of her partner five years her senior we went to antenatal classes together she recalls but everybody was in their late s or s i had the feeling that they were all looking down on us mind you the midwife was lovely when abbie was born it was very difficult with a small baby in somebody elses house so i was really glad to get a place in here she adds gesturing around the communal lounge at acorn court tucked behind lacewindowed semis in a pleasant coventry suburb seven mothers aged between and live here with their children each has a selfcontained flat rather like those in student halls of residence except that there is a cot in every bedroom this is one of two semisupported housing projects in the city run by the charity nacro which is extending its work beyond the care and resettlement of offenders into other areas of social exclusion i suppose you could call it a halfway house says project leader lesley szwed theyre moving from being with parents to being parents themselves there are no staff on the premises at night so if they want to go out they have to arrange their own childcare were trying to build a sense of responsibility so that theyre prepared for life as mothers in the wider community big efforts are made to get these teenagers back into education or training six of the seven are either on courses or about to join one says support worker pearl chick lois for instance has been accepted into the sixth form at her former comprehensive lisa also and with a twoyearold daughter called luisha is doing hairdressing at college and working on saturdays at a citycentre salon lisa is one of acorn courts success stories she had a real attitude problem when she came here says szwed the yearold smiles demurely and lowers her long eyelashes in acknowledgment her hair is immaculate and she is wearing a croptop with an abundance of jewellery on her feet though are slippers that suggest vulnerability a reminder that this young mother is not much more than a child herself they are blue slippers decorated with hearts inside which are inscribed the words hug me for text: one of the problems that have dogged successive governments wanting to help mothers return to work has been the limited availability and high cost of formal childcare two years ago the daycare trust charity declared that britain had the worst childcare provision in europe based on the availability of publicly funded nurseries and ease of parental leave according to the trust the typical cost of a nursery place for a twoyearold is a year in london which is more than the average household spends each year on either food or housing further official estimates suggest there are only registered childcare places for the million children under eight in england new research from economists arnaud chevalier and tarja viitanen presented last week at the annual conference of the royal economic society held at warwick university indicates that a quarter of all mothers of preschool children are not able to access the type of childcare they would prefer and childcare subsidies aimed at helping them combine work with bringing up a family do not appear to help because of this unavailability of preferred care this is because in the language of the economists the supply of formal child care is inelastic to put it in ordinary terms while it has always been assumed that if demand for childcare increased then the price would rise and so would the supply the reality does not follow the theory using data for britain from the s chevalier and viitanen based at the institute for the study of social change at university college dublin argue that the supply of formal childcare does not react to an increase in demand as it should although a rise in demand does lead to a price increase this does not in turn produce an increase in supply as classical economic theory would predict but leads to the formation of a queue for the care that is available the researchers found that of mothers of preschool children were not able to get the nursery place or some other form of formal childcare arrangement that they desired informal care defined in this context as childminders was more pricesensitive and did become more available as the price rose the study found but most mothers did not regard this as an adequate substitute for goodquality nurseries and other forms of more formal care what is needed the researchers argue is a systematic policy of market intervention to extend provision of nurseries cutting the queues and increasing use of childcare because many mothers do not see formal and informal childcare as interchangeable the study suggests an expansion of the former would not lead simply to people transferring from the latter rather it would free nonworking mothers from fulltime caring for their children and enable them to participate more fully in the labour force further information from tarjaviitanenucdie

text: working parents received a big boost in employment rights yesterday with the introduction of several pieces of family friendly legislation the government aims to improve the worklife balance of mothers fathers adoptive parents guardians and foster parents of young or disabled children with new laws on flexible working maternity paternity and adoptive rights sue ashtiary head of employment at law firm nabarro nathanson says the strong emphasis on joint parental responsibility among men and women signals an unprecedented shift in attitudes towards parenting the biggest difference is that it takes away the idea of worklife balance as a womens issue she says thats a big piece of social engineering and there could be a sea change in the way companies and people work for the first time there is now a statutory requirement for employers to provide paternity leave for fathers of children born on or after april the leave has to be taken within days of the birth and as one solid block maternity leave and pay has been extended so that mothers can take up to weeks maternity leave receiving a week or up to of earnings all other rights such as company car holiday rights companywide pay rises etc continue to accrue women who have already worked at a company for weeks or more before becoming pregnant qualify for a further weeks of additional unpaid leave making it a total of a years leave adoptive parents are also eligible for the same rights for the first time as are same sex parents guardians blood adoptive and foster parents with children under the age of six or a disabled child under the age of gain unprecedented rights with the introduction of flexible working rights this enables people to request flexible working arrangements from their employer and that request has to be taken seriously mike emmott advisor at the chartered institute of personnel and development thinks it is one of the most farreaching pieces of employment legislation this government has introduced the right to flexible working is going to have a bigger impact on employers than anything in a long time he says worklife balance is the single biggest workplace issue around at the moment and this legislation will really make employers think about that flexible working hours are more important than money for nearly a third of people looking for a new job according to a survey of jobseekers carried out last november on behalf of the department of trade and industry it found that of parents with children under the age of six regard worklife balance as an important factor when deciding whether to apply for a new job many employers are aware of this and realise that if they want to recruit and retain the best staff flexible working practices have to be an option patricia hewitt secretary of state at the department of trade and industry who is spearheading the reforms says forwardthinking employers are already making steps to comply with the legislation as i go around the country i am very struck by the number of employers who raise the issue with me themselves as they talk about the war for talent she says for this reason i think the majority of employers will offer familyfriendly working under the flexible working procedural requirements regulations legislation any employee with a child under six or a child with a disability under are allowed to request a change in three key areas a change to the hours they work a change to the times of the hours they work andor a change in the place of work for many parents it could be as simple as starting work at am or am instead of am so that they can drop the kids off at school the legislation makes it very clear what is expected of employers and employees when a request for flexible working is made and both parties have to follow the procedure to the letter the employee needs to put the request in writing stating clearly what working arrangements they would like when they want it to come into effect how they think the new arrangement would or would not affect their employer and how to resolve any issues employees can make only one application a year regardless of whether or not previous applications have been successful if the employer agrees to the request they have to inform the employee within days if they want to discuss the request they have to notify the employee in writing and arrange a facetoface interview within days the employee has a right to be accompanied by a colleague or trade union official after that meeting a decision must be made and issued in writing within days there are only eight grounds on which an employer may refuse the request they are the burden of additional costs it would have a detrimental effect on ability to meet customer demand inability to reorganise work among existing staff inability to recruit additional staff detrimental impact on quality detrimental impact on performance insufficiency of work during the periods the employee proposes to work planned structural changes should the employee disagree with the decision he or she has a limited right to appeal the employee cannot challenge the employers business reasons says ashtiary they can only say they didnt follow the correct procedure such as not letting a representative accompany them to the meeting or they can say the decision was based on incorrect facts but what is meant by incorrect facts it is quite a grey area for example is it a fact or a judgment to say whether it will have a detrimental effect on quality or if youre a supervisor and you wont be in on fridays to supervise will it affect quality however ashtiary thinks that the legislation is set out in such a way to try to avoid such situations occurring according to her and other employment experts the emphasis on joint responsibility on both employers and employees to consider the effect of flexible working on business performance should strengthen the employees position providing they make a good business case some critics of the legislation disagree with the introduction of worklife balance initiatives that so explicitly favour parents and parents alone we think the legislation should have been broader because there are many more sources of pressure on people than just bringing up small children says emmott theres caring for older children or elderly relatives for example emmott is also concerned that the legislation will be divisive causing childless professionals to resent the flexible working options granted to colleagues with young children however hewitt says it would not be practicable to have extended the legislation to encompass all employees as far as the law is concerned we were right to say it is about parents with young children or with disabilities because it is important that children can grow up well she says if we had tried to legislate for everybody it would probably never have happened some employers are taking matters into their own hands and making flexible working available to all employees communications provider avaya for example has just made it company policy to allow all employees to request flexible working be they parents or not emmott thinks any companies doing this will reap the benefits as much as their employees will we know that when people have a good worklife balance they have a better attitude towards their job he says they are less likely to make mistakes take sick leave or actually leave but given the current economic climate and pressures on businesses and employees to achieve maximum output ashtiary says it could be a matter of wait and see as only the most enlightened companies might truly embrace flexible working practices at the moment

text: so we are told that the government is taking domestic violence seriously under plans announced at the beginning of the week men convicted of beating their partners are to be placed on a national register modelled on the onefor sex offenders enabling police to track their movements and warn new partners of their past those on the register would be forced to inform local police when they moved home and the list would also be made available to the nhs and social services any move to formalise domestic violence as a major and actionable offence is of course to be welcomed placing it on a par with what is perceived as the most abhorrent offence of our age paedophilia is certainly significant and those who formulated the proposal believe that it will affect public opinion dramatically it would be even more significant if it heralded a muchneeded shift in focus away from the current disproportionate emphasis on street crime which obscures the fact that of violent crime involves a person known to the victim but even before it has begun this register is too little too late in the current context of sentencing for domestic assaults how effective a deterrent can it hope to be although every week in england and wales two women are murdered by a current or former partner it is estimated that only one in five incidents of domestic violence is ever reported fewer still lead to prosecution and only a handful of those result in a custodial sentence of six months or more the qualifying requirement for inclusion on the register in practice the register will only include a minority of the most violent offenders and as one refuge worker put it those stupid enough to get caught agencies dealing with victims of domestic abuse have already suggested that the register would be more effective were it to take into account civil proceedings they estimate that double the number who go through the criminal courts will use the family law act to obtain nonmolestation or residence orders which they find a less stressful and more effective way of dealing with their situation but the current proposals for what is necessary for registration appear set to be as unreflective of the situation on the ground as possible according to civil libertarians the idea that punishment meted out by the courts is not always sufficient sets a dangerous precedent in what other cases would we be willing to deny individuals their right to a clean slate effectively extending their punishment indefinitely these groups have expressed concerns that registers for everything from burglary to shoplifting may follow but tracking by scotland yards hate crimes unit has found that domestically violent men have one of the highest recidivism rates of any offenders and supporters of the scheme argue that we have a duty to protect future victims registration however brings its own difficulties will it as has happened with the sexual offences register feed the notion that domestic offenders are all of a particular type diverting attention from the less palatable truth that violence can happen in any home on any street regardless of race class or education registration also suggests that domestically violent men cannot change their behaviour research by the home office would appear to support this but many academics question these results arguing that the sample used men mandated to attend therapy by the probation service arguably the most violent and intractable individuals was too selective independent evaluation of domestic violence intervention programmes has found that men can and do change but the kind of intervention that works takes time and it doesnt come cheap there is a danger that the operation of a register will simply divert resources from these already chronically underfunded programmes there is also the question of how a register affects daytoday policing policy the centrality of a proarrest policy has been a regular theme of home office guidance on domestic violence in recent years but in practice it remains extraordinarily patchy across the country the womens support charity refuge believes that a concerted arrest and charge strategy would have far more success in preventing domestic abuse than the stigmatisation of a minority of offenders after the fact we dont need more legal remedy but rather adequate implementation of the laws that already exist critics argue that a register does not attack domestic violence at its roots nor does it contribute to our understanding of why it happens in the first place this is a grossly underresearched and underfunded area determinant factors are still only sketchily understood while resources that provide women with options to leave the relationship or to stay safely remain limited those proposing the register believe that it will help to alter public perceptions of the crime by shifting the stigma from victims to perpetrators but is stigmatising the abuser really any better than shaming the abused there is a growing belief among professionals that the naming and shaming of paedophiles simply increases the likelihood of their reoffending by further isolating them from support structures the sex offenders register has demonstrated the limits of the concept interagency tracking is beneficial but how practicable is it to intervene in an offenders future relationships balancing our responsibility towards a potential victim against an individuals right to a private life is a tough call better surely to work towards a situation where it does not take on average instances of violence before a victim contacts the police libbybrookstheguardiancom

text: the government is planning a domestic violence register to monitor men who have convictions for abusing their partners it has emerged it would be modelled on the sex offenders register and could be used to warn women if they were at risk from a new partner campaigners welcomed the proposal but warned that it would tackle only the tip of a very large iceberg because most abusers are never charged katja mahnkopf the policy and communications manager for womens aid said it sends a strong message that domestic violence is not acceptable clearly the intention is to ensure the safety of women and children but it also shows that the perpetrator is being held accountable she said that it would help to protect victims who were followed by their abusers when they moved to a new area by alerting local police but she warned that proposals to inform women that a new partner had a history of violence needed full discussion there are many other measures which need to be put in place to help women such as access to information and support and advocacy services if they decide to take someone to court she said the home office confirmed that the government would publish its domestic violence consultation document next month but refused to discuss its contents details of the proposals contained in a document drawn up by the association of chief police officers acpo and the crown prosecution service were published by the times yesterday the register would hold the details of anyone sentenced to six months or more for assaulting their partner signatories would have to inform the police when they moved the register would also be available to doctors nurses social services and other bodies which could decide to warn a new partner some employers such as the police and social text: every student of sociology has heard of willmott and young and their classic study of workingclass life in east london published in three years later researchers in swansea sought to replicate the study to see if the life of the welsh working classes differed significantly and found that it did not now researchers at the university of swansea have repeated that exercise to see how life has changed in swansea and by implication the rest of britain over the past four decades researchers nickie charles charlotte davies and chris harris last year contacted people covering an area identical to that in the earlier survey perhaps the biggest single difference they found was that the socalled coresident extended family had all but disappeared hardly any of the presentday respondents lived in a threegenerational household grandparents parents and children all under the same roof in one in five households in swansea could be described as extended family in it was just one in however the researchers did find that despite not living at the same address the extended family was still very much alive and well two in three respondents reported having had contact with a nonresident member of their family in the previous week only slightly down on the figure for and in spite of changing gender dynamics womens relationships especially the motherdaughter tie remained at the centre of these extended family groupings the researchers who reported their findings to the recent annual conference in york of the british sociological association found that the composition of swansea households had changed significantly over the past four decades there were slightly fewer containing a married or cohabiting couple and their children compared with in but the proportion of singleperson households had increased to from they also found that of households in were headed by a lone parent although no comparative data is available from it is safe to assume that the number then was considerably lower home ownership had also greatly increased since from to but those describing themselves as middle class had increased only percentage points over the period up from to however almost fewer described themselves as working class the difference being accounted for by a large increase in the other category including respondents describing themselves as human or are what you are another major finding of the swansea team was the decline in religiosity over the past four decades religion has long played an important part in the cultural and political life of wales and this was definitely still true of swansea in when of the sample said they had attended a place of worship within the previous week in this figure had fallen to just and of those questioned denied any religious connection whatsoever further information at wwwswanacuksssidindexhtm

the centre with two to fouryearolds for around an hour why do i do it because i love it he says ive always wanted to work with children and now i am im happy the theme of next months national more men childcare providers will have to provide positive images a shakeup in training a change among careers advisors and a hike in pay but who will foot the bill peter moss argues that childcare text: legislation to tackle domestic violence will be introduced this autumn the home secretary david blunkett promised yesterday the package will for the first time give police the power of arrest in cases of common assault make criminal penalties available for those who breach court orders and create a limited national register of those orders victims will also be granted anonymity if fear of identification deters them from giving evidence but a home office consultation paper published yesterday makes clear that several proposals which had been strongly backed by the solicitor general harriet harman are unlikely to be in the legislation when it is published later this year they include changes to the defences of provocation self defence and diminished responsibility in murder cases and plans for a national register of domestic violence offenders there was a broad welcome for the package when it was announced in the commons yesterday with mps from all parties expressing a strong commitment to tackle a problem which had often been regarded as taboo one woman in four will experience domestic violence in their lifetime every single minute of every day a domestic violence assault is reported to the police it can occur irrespective of background or circumstances race or gender but it is predominantly women who suffer said mr blunkett we are determined to do more to tackle this evil crime which devastates families and ruins lives domestic violence is often a hidden crime which victims suffer in silence and isolation the decision to make common assault an arrestable offence is designed to ensure that the police adopt a proarrest policy when they respond to a domestic violence call this will allow the police to find and arrest the offender if as is not uncommon he has already left the scene by the time they get there the register of civil orders will allow the police to check for outstanding orders against an alleged offender when they respond to a call but it has been decided to ask the law commission to report on proposed changes to the defence of provocation in murder cases it has been asked to report by spring leaving open the question of whether it will be in time for next years legislation responding to the proposals the torys shadow minister for women caroline spelman warned the government needs to be careful not to introduce unenforceable legislation in an area where lives need to be saved sandra gidley mp the liberal democrat spokesperson on women criticised violent partners still being permitted unsupervised access to their children in situations where a child was in potential danger this amounts to gambling with a childs welfare she said that criticism was reiterated by the nspcc and womens aid charities who said that since at least children had been killed in england and wales during contact visits andrew mcfarlane qc chair of the family law bar association applauded the measures to ensure the criminal and civil justice systems worked more closely together but the solicitors family law association insisted victims should retain the right to choose to use the civil system alone for many sufferers the need for a safe home for their children will be a more pressing priority than a criminal conviction to punish the perpetrator it said

text: changing public attitudes is the most difficult task facing any government moving money between programmes is much easier but the past three decades have demonstrated that attitudes can be changed thirty years ago there was little public concern about child abuse now people from all walks of life have been alerted to the danger yesterday will be marked as the day when social attitudes towards domestic violence began to make a similar significant shift the ultimate aim is to ensure the public become as concerned about violence against partners as violence against a child all three main political parties signalled their support for a green paper on the issue published by the home office yesterday a draft bill has been promised for later in the year the first significant change in the law for years it is the biggest victory yet for the large intake of women mps who were elected in the political agenda is being feminised plain facts underline the urgency of changing the current law the british crime survey suggests domestic violence accounts for of all violence about incidents are recorded every year of the victims being women men surveys suggest women can suffer incidences or more before reporting their partners to the police about people are killed each year in these confrontations some of them women the effects on children can be equally serious making them fearful withdrawn and anxious about one in every six women seeking homeless accommodation for themselves and their children is a victim of violence they account for placements in the last seven years text: the home secretary david blunkett today announced wideranging plans to protect victims of domestic violence and ensure that people who beat their partners are brought to justice introducing the consultation paper safety and justice mr blunkett said one woman in four will experience domestic violence in their lifetime every single minute of every day a domestic violence assault is reported to the police it can occur irrespective of background or circumstance race or gender but it is predominantly women who suffer the government is determined to do more to tackle this evil crime which devastates families and ruins lives domestic violence is often a hidden crime which victims suffer in silence and isolation it has many causes many forms but it is important that the system is coherent and effective and able to help prevent such violence as well as tackling the underlying causes mr blunkett told mps that the government proposed to make common assault an arrestable offence the move would mean that suspected perpetrators can be quickly removed from the scene of an attack the use of restraining orders would be widened in cases where there was insufficient evidence for a criminal conviction but would be sufficient to justify safeguards being put in place he said the paper also proposes anonymity for victims and witnesses to make it easier to report cases specialist courts could be further developed and there would be consultation on the creation of a register of civil orders to enable police to know at the time of a domestic incident whether the suspect had breached an order and could be arrested stressing that sentences must reflect the crimes committed mr blunkett said that the law commission was being asked to look at defences offered in homicide cases the defence of provocation for example often relies on sexual jealousy as justification of murder this is not acceptable he said the first hour national helpline for victims was being set up and ministers would examine ways of ensuring it was the perpetrator of violence not the victim who had to move out of the family home mr blunkett said all too often victims suffered silently from this hidden crime he added the proposals also include spending m to create extra places at shelters for victims of domestic violence mr blunkett also said that he was consulting on a possible domestic violence offenders register but warned that there were practical difficulties which could stand in its way research showed that one in five young men and one in ten young women believed that violence two weeks and dealing with contracts worth millions of pounds it was a company id set up myself and it was flourishing id married two and a half years before and everything was going smoothly until we talked about having children the sort of life i was living meant that i wouldnt have heard my childrens first words and almost certainly wouldnt have been able to get back in time to even see them born i had two choices i could see my children for four days every two weeks or i could look for a job that let me be a proper dad once i thought about it like that i didnt really have a choice if you want to have an influence on your childrens upbringing you have to be there to do it its far too easy to realise too late that youve missed your childrens youth and after all your children only develop once and need you to be there once i finished the contract i was working on at the time and came straight back home now i earn a third of what i previously made which was hard to get used to although i wasnt entirely stupid i made absolutely sure i had a proper pension and boosted my savings as much as i could beforehand i used to own a company with a turnover of m now i work for the it department of a company whose entire turnover is worth less than most of the individual projects i used to handle sure thats hard to get used to but once i got used to my bank balance and the lack of importance of my position i found the lack of responsibility an enormous relief being able to go home at pm and pass the buck on to someone else was hugely liberating our friends found it difficult to understand the choice i made some thought i was completely mad but if i ever get the occasional twang of regret for the excitement of my past job i realise that the rewards of watching my children grow up outweigh everything i have lost jon cooper below is and single with no children i was earning four times as much as a lawyer for a corporation in the leisure sector when i decided to move to a childrens charity as an inhouse lawyer it was quite unusual for a single man with no children in the world of law to make that sort of choice and no corporation would countenance the suggestion the corporate world of law is completely wrapped up in the english macho attitude that sucks as many hours out of its employees as possible mentioning that i was concerned about the quality of my life would have damaged my career to the point where i would have been thrown to the bottom of the heap its transformed my life im a happier and more stressfree person and i probably get more work done in was so successful it would barely impact on our overall income liz is going to go back to work a month or so after having the baby and why not she loves working and is fantastic at it and because of her success i can now do exactly what ive always wanted to do too and why shouldnt i ive been working to earn money since i was and not wanting to while liz would hate to stay at home im happier than i ever had the right to expect i would be before i met liz after the baby is born im going to be a fulltime parent for the first six months and then the main carer for the rest of the childs life i feel hugely privileged that i can do that i cant think of a more brilliant way to live my life and i think most men of my generation would agree if only they were lucky enough to have the same choice ive got friends who are doctors and lawyers and theyre all a bit nonplussed by our decision but i think that when they see how happy liz and i are going to be when our family starts to grow and how happy our kids will be that theyll soon wish their careers were flexible enough for them to make a similar choice when that moment comes i really hope theyll press their employers to give them the text: rhian wheeler is so petite that she barely looks her years cheerful confident and full of energy she is also the mother of monthold scarlett and the exact opposite of the stereotype of a typical teenage mum having started back at college after scarletts birth and with only her final few exams left to go rhian is aiming for a career as a legal secretary and is bubbling with enthusiasm about her future its thanks to several factors that she feels this way a supportive family and her own positive attitude not the least of them from early in her pregnancy however rhian also had the backing of the stockport young parents project coordinated by alison lockley the project is one of five pilots established in by the department for education and skills the others being camden cornwall oldham and middlesbrough to see if providing support mechanisms would help parents aged to explore further education and training even thinking about going to college would have been a lot more difficult if it hadnt been for alisons help says rhian when youre pregnant youve got so much on your mind you just go oh ill think about college tomorrow and maybe youre a bit nervous too because on open days they have hundreds of people to deal with its not always easy to face that but i do my course fulltime now and more than anything its the childcare going to college would just be impossible without it access to childcare is the biggest obstacle to young mothers in stockport going further in their education believes ms lockley there are other difficulties such as identifying the right course and getting through the application process often they need help mediating with the college if problems arise but ive found that reliable childcare is the one key factor that has enabled teenage mothers to access education this project can fund whatever kind of childcare a mother is most comfortable with whether thats a private nursery or a childminder or friends and relatives initially the young women referred to the project often chose vocational courses in hairdressing beauty childcare and computer skills they are now extending their choices to a wider range of subjects including graphic design teaching qualifications sports science and health and social sciences ms lockley emphasises the importance of supporting young women to be fulltime mothers if that is what they want but points out that lone parenting is an isolating experience teenage mums may not exactly choose to be fulltime carers but simply fall into it through lack of options her own research shows that different groups of young mothers have widely varying attitudes to education some of the young women referred to me were absolutely adamant that formal education was not for them but you cant give up you have to try to keep a dialogue going because at some point in the future they might want to think again these efforts have been testing in the extreme the stockport young parents project decided that a policy of total flexibility in interpreting education and training was required for the hardesttoreach mothers and a series of workshops were set up in response to questionnaires the young women had filled in despite offering free transport organised childcare refreshments and a range of topics to fit in with their expressed interests the sessions were poorly attended it was clear that new thinking was needed interagency cooperation was prioritised with the aim of drawing on all the relationships teenage mothers had developed with the stockport youth service and the local irwell housing association by pooling resources and relationships there is now a fluctuating group of young women attending some form of educational activity every week workshops have been held on health and safety welfare benefits and first aid this may not appear to be proper education indeed ms lockley admits that its a small start and all the agencies involved are feeling their way certainly these mums are unlikely to be hopping merrily from babies to exams to gainful employment in the near future however she says once you get someone engaged in something then theres an opportunity which could be vital to that young woman later on there have been genuine success stories two of the young mothers supported by the project are now thinking seriously about university since teenage mothers and one teenage father have received direct services that have meant they could go on to college or vocational training but as rhian wheeler explains its when she thinks of starting a job without the personal and financial support offered by the project that life begins to feel precarious again the government will pay of scarletts childcare but ill still have to find around a month out of my wages and theres likely to be a backlog anyway that ill have to fund if i want to do any more studying ill be past the age for alisons project and im not sure how i would manage it the dfes has just announced that all parents aged to will have their childcare costs met in full as long as they are in formal education or workbased learning however ms lockley points out that this still leaves young mothers over who want to pursue further or higher education in a difficult position these are often very vulnerable people often not articulate or organised or able to deal with the system some colleges do offer childcare places but theyre limited and you have to work to get them thats why simply paying for childcare isnt the whole solution to helping young women restart their education often they need onetoone support and liaison between agencies as well as mediation throughout their college course to help them succeed

text: in the beginning new labour put all its hope into early years education it was the way to raise standards in schools by having children well prepared to learn it was the way to raise scores at and gcse pass rates this was the great longterm hope to transform the social devastation of the tory years that left onethird of britains children born poor so in speech after speech now you still hear labour ministers extolling the value of sure start the dream was that a poor baby born under labour in would by the year have grown up filled with hope and opportunity those at risk of failing would be helped before they were born their parents helped to cope after birth with home support followed later by childcare to help every mother to go out to work the child would get not just quality care at all hours but nursery education of the best sadly it hasnt worked out that way for very many families of course the tories did not regard childcare as a state function at all which made it hard to get single mothers into work even nursery education was marginal experimenting with vouchers that failed at least labour from the start acknowledged the need and obligation of the state to provide this missing plank in the welfare state so one way or another often hand to mouth nursery education provision has soared by september all three and fouryearolds will get the basic minimum but childcare is another story according to the latest figures the daycare trust reckons it is only available for one in seven children and many of those places are private and far beyond the reach of most families there are separate possible funding streams for early years a nightmare for hardpressed nurseries to navigate because of the chaos of local versus central funding local councils are fiddling their books the results are often insane because there will be money for childrens centres m spread over three years only m this year kensington and chelsea council is closing wellestablished nurseries caring for children at risk ainsworth nursery is to be redesignated as a childrens centre to qualify for new funds but nearly all its children will be removed and put into a primary school only eight children will still get nursery schooling the minimum to qualify as a wraparound childrens centre and this fiddling and rebadging is happening everywhere it is hard to tell what is new provision and what is rebadged labour has not abandoned the dream but progress is slow as it failed to move early years to the top of the education agenda with all the public clamour from the text: clara furse is the first woman to be chief executive of the london stock exchange and last week she made yet another assault on the record books when it emerged that her new salary package will total over m a year whatever the rights and wrongs of a salary that size it is progress of a kind for women there is also a touch of irony in that furse has risen to the top of a sector in which generally womens salaries lag far behind mens there is no dispute that furse deserves such a package in so far as anybody does in all likelihood she is not the first woman in the city to breach the m mark just the first obliged to make it public by weight of numbers finance ceased to be a mans world a decade ago the majority of workers in the industry are women by a slender but growing margin but the gap between what these women earn compared with men is far from slender the average hourly rate for women is barely half that of the male equivalent it is the widest gap in any industry the principal cause of this is that women are disproportionately spread between admin and management while they are the majority in the city only onefifth of them are in management the reason so many women choose to work in finance is the availability of flexible working at the end of the s when the highstreet banks began processing paperwork centrally overnight instead of in the branches the natural recruits to do the work were women who had had banking experience before leaving to have children they welcomed the opportunity to work parttime at odd hours today a third of all women in the industry are parttimers that same flexibility has not spread to management however which is why there are far more women at the bottom of the pyramid than at the top managers are paid a larger basic salary and also bolster their packages with bonuses hence the very wide pay gap in fact furses package makes the m mark through bonuses her basic salary is actually slightly smaller than her predecessor

text: recent legal changes have promised much for working parents extended maternity leave paternity leave and parental leave all sound as if they will be of enormous help to parents aiming to achieve the governments worklife balance goals but reading between the lines produces a different picture in fact there is little financial incentive for parents to take advantage of these new benefits april this year saw the dawn of paternity leave fathers with six months service at a company are now legally entitled to two weeks paternity leave for the first time sounds like a good thing yes but many fathers may less enthusiastic about taking their leave when they discover that their paternity pay is set at per week or of pay for those who habitually earn less than this the good news for dads is that most employers are ahead of the game with eight out of offering up to three days fully paid leave not all are as cooperative however according to support body parents at work some companies still warn staff that more than a few days leave will be detrimental to business greater and greater numbers of women are nowadays entitled to take maternity leave with entitlement recently extended to those who started their jobs six months before the th week of their pregnancy new mothers will receive support for weeks rather than the previous and leave will be granted for a further weeks meaning mothers will be able to spend a total of one year away from work however the second week period will be unpaid compelling most mothers to return to the office sooner than they might wish rachel roe legal adviser for parents at work which is calling for a longer earningsrelated pay period points out the difficulties that new mothers are facing mothers are returning to work early because they are so close to the line in needing their pay she says this year also saw the beginnings of what is supposed to be a more flexible era of work for parents and other workers although employers are now legally bound to consider parents requests for flexitime there is no evidence yet of any practical change despite predictions by the department for trade and industry dti that working parents will benefit from new arrangements lowincome groups are less likely to be taken seriously in requesting flexible working many businesses are unfamiliar with their new obligations and were hearing reports of kneejerk negative reactions from employers says roe this picture is backed up by research from the chartered institute of personnel and development cipd the institute reported last year that one in working parents said their employer did not understand parental responsibilities with manufacturing and production industries most culpable despite flexible working policies half the parents interviewed worried about having to leave on time particularly those in the service industry the private sector is meaner with flexitime with only one quarter of businesses offering it compared to of public sector organisations parental leave was introduced three years ago offering parents and guardians weeks leave until their childs fifth birthday or until a disabled child is up to a maximum of four weeks a year the leave remains unpaid however and parents must take a minimum of one week rather than a day at any one time according to the cipds mike emmott takeup has not been significant for short periods of time staff may play it by ear and take a day sick day or two in order to cope with something urgent he says working parents still face problems finding childcare with only of organisations questioned by the cipd offering a workplace nursery and childcare subsidies a figure which actually represents a fall from three years ago government plans to provide tax incentives for employerprovided childcare may increase work facilities from next april for now only of parents use professional childcare with high cost being the biggest barrier juggling is the norm for one in five working parents who manage to look after their own children and work while one in three depend on their partner and a quarter rely on another family member even with taking into account the recent changes people on lower incomes may be more reluctant to forego full pay in order to take maternity paternity or parental leave and men are particularly slow in taking up the leave to which theyre entitled with of males with dependent children still in fulltime work the number of women going back to work is growing with of women returning to the office within months of their childs birth in compared to in yet with little financial incentive for men to take time off it is still the case that on the whole mother is left holding the baby

retirement we would refuse to give up what weve got we would have antiage discrimination laws so that no one could ever force us out of our jobs so here we go or rather here we stay forever talking
